awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Feedbacks between Orographic Precipitation and Ice Dynamics
awd_abstract_narration:
Aschwanden/1644277

This award supports a project to study the phenomenon of the rain shadow (technically called orographic precipitation) in the Antarctic Peninsula and its interaction with a mountain range covered in ice and snow. Orographic precipitation gives rise to the largest climatic and ecological gradients on Earth.  Air ascending on the windward side of the mountain range expands and cools, condensing the water vapor it carries and producing heavy rain- or snow-fall. As the air descends on the leeward flank, the air warms and dries out, leaving little-to-no precipitation.  This pattern of snowfall, caused by the interaction of winds and the landscape, is hypothesized to control the shape of the ice cap itself. The investigators hypothesize that feedbacks between precipitation and topography control ice flux and temperature, impacting basal conditions (frozen versus wet) and motion, which over long time scales can affect basal topography via erosion.

The authors propose to investigate the feedbacks between orographically driven precipitation, ice dynamics, thermodynamics, and basal erosion and uplift over the northern Antarctic Peninsula by coupling an orographic precipitation model to the Parallel Ice Sheet Model (PISM). Using idealized and more realistic geometries, they will begin with a 2-D flow band model, which will be expanded into three dimensions to determine the strength of the feedbacks as a function of bedrock geometry and the intensity of the orographic precipitation gradient. The Antarctic Peninsula is targeted as the ideal case study, in the context of its rapid modern and future change as well as its deflation since the Last Glacial Maximum.  The broader impacts of the work include the strengthening of predictive models by capturing feedbacks related to orographic precipitation not included in current models. This is likely to provide a more realistic assessment of the impacts of orographic precipitation in a regime of changing climate. The project will support an early career scientist and a female mid-career scientist and will support one PhD student, and provide summer research experience for one undergraduate student as an REU supplement.  The project does not require field work in the Antarctic.

por.por_cntn:
This project was joint between the University of Alaska, Faribanks, and the University of Washington, Seattle.

The original motivation was prompted by the recognition of a very interesting ice-cap configuration in the Antarctic peninsula. An extremely strong (ten-fold) west-to-east precipitation gradient exists across an ice cap with shorter upwind flank (10 km wide) and a longer (50 km wide) downwind flank. Despite intense upwind precipitation, the largest overall ice fluxes are observed on the eastern flank. Two factors contribute to this – the larger width and larger catchment areas of the eastern flank.  How can this configuration of ice topography, basal topography, and climate arise in this setting? What do the interactions between these three processes in this setting tell us about their interaction in other settings?

 

A common paradigm is that large ice-streams are ‘self perpetuating’ via what might be termed positive feedbacks. For instance, a larger-than-average ice stream can grow at the expense of neighboring streams – the higher flux there leads to both increased head-ward and lateral erosion, so capturing more catchment area and further increasing the flux. In addition, on erosional timescales, larger fluxes are thought to lead to larger basal erosion rates. As the valley deepens ice will fill the hole (ice flow abhors surface gradients), and ice flux is a sensitive nonlinear function of ice-thickness, typically varying as the fourth or fifth power of ice thickness.

The smaller UW portion of the proposal was to investigate the coupling of ice sheets with the pattern of precipitation (i.e., snowfall) created by the interaction of the atmosphere and ice. Ice flow is highly viscous, and our UW results show this means that a strong gradient in precipitation (sometimes termed rain shadow) causes a relatively muted response of the ice-sheet shape. We demonstrated that the basal topography was the strongest control on the shape of the overlying ice cap. Our results provide predictions for the modeling efforts using more complex numerical models in larger UAF portion of the work.

Other aspects of UW research explored the dynamics of fast-moving and potentially unstable ice streams in Antarctica such as those that predicted to contribute to sea-level rise in future centuries. Our research showed such ice streams adjust in two stages, and that simple mathematical models of those two stages can be used to understand the how natural variability ocean and atmospheric forcing of such ice streams affects the predictability of future changes. Finally, another climate-ice interaction was studied: floods from melting glaciers are a serious natural hazard. One such setting in Peru was the target of a undergraduate summer research project.
